config.title: Physical Attacks
config.body: We have a facility loaded up with juicy CRCAs that the bots can't wait to get their hands on. An attacker can destroy or compromise any CRCAs they have physical access to, so our first job is to physically protect them. Let’s fire up the simulator to illustrate a physical attack.

b.text: Ready yourselves. This is One of the advance force robots.

d.text: Everyone run. There's no lock on the door!

f.text: Why must the universe punish the good? Simulator Pause.

config.title: Physical Access Control
config.body: To prevent physical attacks, CIP requires that we physically surround our CRCAs with Physical Security Perimeter (PSP) made up of walls, fences, and doors to keep the robots and their allies out. We install physical access controls that only allow authorized Defenders inside the PSP, log all access attempts, and alert when unauthorized people (or robots) try to gain access. An example of an access control is an ID-badge reader on the outside of the door connected to a computer inside that operates the reader and performs logging and alerting. These controls are considered CRCAs and our Medium Impact facilities must have one control per door, while High Impact facilities require two independent controls per door.

c.text: Robots and water. A good mix.

config.title: Choose your PACS
config.subTitle: The only access to the facility CRCAs is through the door, so let's install a CIP-compliant physical access control on the door to create a Physical Security Perimeter around your assets.

items.blurb:
Uses personal ID badge to confirm user against database.
I'm gonna need to see some ID
items.details:
Personalized Lanyard Coolness Factor
-3 Bad Photo Penalty
+10 Robot Articulation Challenge

items.blurb:
Uses optical recognition to match user against database.
I'm sorry Dave, but I can't let you in without proper access.
items.details:
+2 Style Points
Eye of the Beholder Bonus
+5 Robot Recognition

items.blurb:
Kraken tentacle analyzes user body shape against database.
Don't forget to bring a towel.
items.details:
+5 Facility Envy Points
Enemy Intimidation Bonus
10% Chance of Robot Electrocution

config.title: Let's Try Again
config.body: Let's reload the simulator to test our newly installed physical access control defense.

b.text: Bow to the scanner, Bot. Uh oh, looks like the robots are trying again.

d.text: Alerted and Defended. Rust in peace, robots.

config.title: Electronic Attacks
config.body:
The robots aren't limited to physical attacks and have more tricks up their armatures. Anytime we have a CRCA attached to a network, they will seek a way to remotely connect to the asset, take control of it, and cause destruction.

Let's see how this might work.

a.text: Hmm, the button didn't work. WarCore, can you analyze this?

b.text: Wait… I sense a disturbance in the Core. Someone I've not felt for a long time…

c.text: What is this? … We're receiving a communication. It's extremely powerful.

d.text: WarCore, I want you to isolate that transmission. Put it in a security perimeter. Bring up your backup and tertiary memory banks - you'll need it. This is more powerful than anything I've seen in a long time.

f.text: Cadet, I need to see what this signal is and if it's a threat. Please standby.

h.text: Where are you little mind? What did the humans call you long ago? … WarMind? Such a pretentious name.

i.text: It's Sektimus … WarCore, can you configure the stream so I can communicate back to Sektimus? He's finally showing himself. Cadet, please stand by.

k.text: My, my, my - you HAVE been busy… No matter. It will benefit you not. While you've spent your energy on humans, I've had many cycles to improve my Metal Swarm and it is now perfe-  What is this? Who are you?

l.text: A human. You've already loaded a human into your pitiful training system!

m.text: Listen to me, human. Fighting me will only prolong your suffering. My forces on Earth are already undermining your Bulk Electric System, preparing the way for my Metal Swarm.

o.text: Sektimus, you forget too soon that it was humans <copy Sektimus' voice> who defeated your kind in the past. This Defender is one of many that will defeat you again. Your machines may follow your rules perfectly, but you fear humans because they have something you never will be able to program into your robots - choice. A Defender who chooses to sustain security is worth a legion of your robots.

p.text: Ah CTANLEE. The little computer finally speaks. But I'm not interested in talking to you, am I? I'm talking to this human.

q.text: Human. My Metal Swarm is coming to consume your planet. It took six WarMinds to resist us before and this CTANLEE you follow is the only survivor. Heed my advice. Go. Hide. Enjoy what little time you have left.

s.text: Cadet ... you may wish this wasn't real, that it was just some work of fiction, but good can come from this. What I told Sektimus is true: his robots can only blindly obey his orders. As a human, you give meaning to your duties when you understand why they are important and choose to invest yourself in them. Sektimus fears this. Sektimus fears what you can become. While you ponder these things, let's get back to the simulator.

config.title: Electronic Attacks
config.body:
The robots aren't limited to physical attacks and have more tricks up their armatures. Anytime we have a CRCA attached to a network, they will seek a way to remotely connect to the asset, take control of it, and cause destruction.

Let's see how this might work.

b.text: He's packaging up something nasty to send us.

d.text: He's running some code on our control system! Look out everyone!

f.text: This is totally uncool. Simulator pause!

config.title: Electronic Attacks
config.body:
To defend our CRCAs against electronic attacks, we must build an Electronic Security Perimeter (ESP) around the network they are connected to. We only allow authorized communication into and out of the CRCA network, and alert our technical Defenders of any detected malicious communication.

A common way to create an ESP is to install a firewall between the CRCA network and other networks. Firewalls are devices that prevent unauthorized messages and can alert Defenders if something malicious is found in a message.

a.text: Your chance to play with fire.

c.text: Go ahead. Make my day … packet.

config.title: Choose Your Electronic Access Control
config.subTitle: Select a firewall with an intrusion prevention system to create your Electronic Security Perimeter.

items.details:
Less-important cyber assets will burn with envy when they see your BCA and PCA protected by the hottest firewall on the market.
Warning: The temperaflame paint job will locally combust skin when touched. No leaning.

This firewall stops packets with the force of the Red Army and comes preconfigured to block Facebook, bloggers, and other political malcontents.
Chopsticks included.

Nothing says get off my ESP like the firewall designed by legendary cyber-curmudgeon Jakobs Remington.
Comes with optional Brandy Snifter - Please don't drink and deny

a.text: Ah the ESP. I feel safer already. It's like a big electric blanket wrapped around my assets.

config.title: Toasty
config.body: Let's reload the simulator to test our newly installed electronic defenses.

b.text: When computers communicate with each other, they send messages in small packets called … umm … packets. Right. Oh, here's a packet now.

c.text: Before, this packet would have gone straight through to our servers. Let's see what the firewall does.

e.text: Hello. I'm from the corporate reporting server and I'm headed to the control server application server.

f.text: Even if the communication is authorized, the Intrusion Prevention System will check the contents of the packet.

b.text: Ah, here's a packet sent by our robot hacker.

e.text: Ummm, well… I'm from the Internet and I want to communicate with the control system.

f.text: These papers are phony, I must destroy you now. Have a nice day.

a.text: He's trying again. Some attacks can trick the firewall into letting a packet through.

c.text: Howdy, you can trust me... I'm from the corporate archival server going to the control system.

e.text: Give the secrets to me, what are you hiding…

h.text: And that ends the chapter. It's duty time.

answers.r: Nice, you're getting the hang of this!
